pageMeta.description: Emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) from human activities disturb the radiative energy balance of the earth-atmosphere system. They exacerbate the natural greenhouse effect, leading to temperature changes and other disruption of the earth's climate. Land use changes and forestry also play a role by altering the amount of greenhouse gases captured or released by carbon sinks

content.value: Air pollution is the leading environmental health risk in Latin America and the Caribbean and a major cause of environmental degradation (Pan American Health Organization, 2023). In Central and South America, rapid urban development and industrialisation, as well as increased energy transformation and consumption, in particular from vehicle emissions and stationary-source fuel combustion, are the main contributors to local air pollution, concentrated in population-dense cities. In the Caribbean, industrialisation, coupled with poor land use (i.e., the distribution of commercial, industrial, and high-density residential areas with parks and green areas) and waste management have also seen rapidly worsening air quality.

Exposure to air pollution is particularly high in urban areas where economic activity is concentrated and where demand for mobility is highest. Cities worst affected by air pollution include Monterrey, Guadalajara, Mexico City, Cochabamba, Santiago, Lima, Bogotá, Medellín, Montevideo and San Salvador, all of which exceed the concentration levels recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO) (WHO, 2022). Large differences also exist between population and income groups, with worse outdoor air pollution affecting households located near roads and industrial sites, and worse indoor air pollution due to the use of solid fuels (such as coal, firewood, anthracite and charcoal) as the principal domestic fuel. In some cases, differences in air exposure are linked to inequalities in the development, implementation and compliance of environmental law, policy, and regulation (PAHO, 2023).

Poor air quality stemming from pollutants such as nitrogen dioxide, sulphur dioxide, ozone and black carbon have substantial economic and social consequences, from health costs and a lower quality of life to infrastructure maintenance, reduced agricultural output and forest damage. For example, pollutant emissions have brought about disturbances to the evaporation rate and atmospheric humidity in South America, thereby decreasing precipitation in the Amazon basin (Koren et al., 2004). Some population groups are especially vulnerable to air pollution, the very young and the very old being the most at risk. However, information on the magnitude and incidence of specific health effects of air pollutants in the region is lacking,

is a local air pollutant that seriously affects human health, predominantly caused by the increase in motorisation in the region, specifically diesel motors, the use of wood as fuel, and wildfires. Chronic exposure even to moderate levels of PM

substantially increases the risk of heart disease and stroke and is an important cause of death in LAC countries (GBD, 2019). It also increases the risk of respiratory diseases, including lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and respiratory infections. Black carbon, a major component of PM

is linked to the accelerated loss of Andean glaciers, which has decreased fourfold in size from 1964-1975 to 2010 (Rabatel et al., 2013), affecting the livelihoods of 85 million Andean inhabitants living across Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Perú and Venezuela, 20 million of which depend on the glaciers for drinking water and agriculture; as well as presenting issues for the generation of hydroelectric energy, a central source of energy in the region (WB; ICCI, 2013).

Air emissions can be reduced by substituting dirty fuels for cleaner ones, focusing development on cleaner industries, reducing consumption of polluting products and adopting cleaner technologies. Behavioural and lifestyle changes are also important.

Policies that provide incentives across a broad spectrum of firms and consumers (e.g. emission or energy taxes) tend to be more cost-efficient than those that target a specific product, fuel or technology (e.g. subsidies for electric cars).

Both the sources of air pollution and severity of exposure vary across and within countries. Hence it is important to tailor policies to specific local circumstances. For example, more stringent measures are required in densely populated areas or for emission sources located upwind from urban areas. Such spatially heterogeneous policies help achieve environmental objectives at lower costs than measures that apply uniformly to sources in all locations and to populations at all risk levels.

Although air-quality standards have been established in some Latin American countries, these are frequently exceeded. Most cities in the region do not have standards for fuel efficiency, vehicle emissions or fuel quality, which are generally considered to be clean transportation standards. Air quality standards are not consistently enforced in many Caribbean countries.

Environmental performance can be assessed against domestic objectives and international commitments. Reducing negative impacts of degraded air quality is part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development (New York, September 2015) under
“Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages”
“Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable”

Progress can be assessed by measuring the evolution of emissions, the exposure of population to air pollutants, the related health effects and their costs, and the evolution of policy stringency directed at pricing air pollution. The costs of air pollution mainly arise from its detrimental impact on human health. These take the form of shorter life expectancy, increased healthcare costs and reduced labour productivity. Further consequences include reduced agricultural output and damage to ecosystems and built structures.

Population exposure to fine particulate matter in LAC has been driven by rapid urbanisation in the region, accompanied by high exposure to both mobile and stationary air pollution sources from vehicles, industry and energy production. The motorisation in the LAC region reached 200 vehicles per thousand inhabitants in 2015, with the countries with the highest rates being Barbados, Suriname, Bahamas, Argentina and Mexico. In absolute terms, countries with the highest number of combustion vehicles are Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Colombia, Venezuela, Puerto Rico and Peru (ECLAC, 2018). Mean population exposure to PM

has slowly decreased from an average of 23 micrograms per cubic metre across the LAC region in 1990 to 17.8 micrograms per cubic metre in 2019, remaining significantly above the guideline set by the WHO of annual mean concentrations of PM

not exceeding 5 micrograms per cubic metre, the lowest range over which adverse health effects can be observed. Currently, all countries in the region exceed this guideline, the highest being Peru, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, Belize, Grenada and Chile.
Urban planning and policies to green the transport system have the power to significantly reduce PM

pollution levels. Understanding the relationship between pollution levels and characteristics of the urban environment is particularly useful for policymakers in the context of limited air quality data, as policy-amenable features of cities with a proven association with pollution levels can be targeted to protect population health and the environment. These characteristics include city density, fragmentation, congestion, quality of public transportation and quantity of green spaces (Gouveia et al., 2021). For example, the higher population density in the Caribbean islands, combined with a more concentrated network of road infrastructure are likely to be behind high population exposure to air pollution, more so than a high motorisation rate. The reverse is true for South America. Socio-economic inequality also plays a significant role in exposure to pollution, the latter being negatively correlated with per capita household income (IDB, 2022).

content.value: Expressed as the mass of PM2.5 per cubic meter. Calculated as the mean annual outdoor PM2.5 concentration weighted by population living in the relevant area, that is, the concentration level, expressed in μg/m3, to which a typical resident is exposed throughout a year.

The guideline set by the World Health Organization (WHO) for PM2.5 is that annual mean concentrations should not exceed 5 micrograms per cubic meter, representing the lower range over which adverse health effects have been observed. The WHO has also recommended guideline values for emissions of PM2.5 from burning fuels in households.
Source: OECD, “Air quality and health: Exposure to PM2.5 fine particles – countries and regions”, OECD Environment Statistics (database),
Mortality attributed to exposure to fine particulates

Fine particulate emissions are responsible for a large number of premature deaths in LAC countries. Linked to respiratory infections, ischemic heart disease and stroke, cancer and chronic respiratory diseases, an average of 7.3 premature deaths per million inhabitants is attributed to PM

). Although mortality rates attributable to pollution is lower in the LAC region than in Sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, East Asia and the Pacific, they are higher than in North America, Europe and Central Asia, and Middle East and North Africa (WHO, 2022).

Fine particulate emissions are responsible for a large number of avoidable premature deaths in LAC countries. Linked to respiratory infections, ischemic heart disease and stroke, cancer and chronic respiratory diseases, an average of 3.53 deaths per million inhabitants is attributed to PM

across the region (World Bank, 2022). Although age-standardised deaths attributable to pollution is lower in the LAC region than in Sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, East Asia and the Pacific they are higher than in North America, Europe and Central Asia, and Middle East and North Africa. Within the region, the incidence of mortality attributed to PM
is evenly spread across the three sub-regions, with Peru, Grenada, Barbados, Colombia, Bolivia, Chile, Cuba and Ecuador presenting the highest mortality rates.

In 2019, chronic respiratory diseases caused over 180,000 deaths in the LAC region, most of which were due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Brazil has the highest number of deaths related to chronic respiratory diseases in absolute terms, with 77 700 in 2019, followed by Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela, Peru, Cuba, Ecuador and Bolivia. Chronic respiratory diseases account for a significant proportion of premature death (PAHO, 2021).

Chronic respiratory diseases account for a significant proportion of Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) in the region; for instance, over 3 million DALYs were lost in South America in 2019, followed by 1.25 million in Central and North America, and 430 thousand in the Caribbean (PAHO, 2021).
Within the region, the incidence of mortality attributed to PM

is evenly spread across the three sub-regions, with Peru, Grenada, Barbados, Colombia, Bolivia, Chile, Cuba and Ecuador presenting the highest mortality rates. In absolute terms, the total number of premature deaths in the region reached 168 thousand in 2019, increasing from 102 thousand in 1990. Moreover, despite mean population exposure to particulate matter has fallen mortality attributed to exposure to PM
has increased from an average of 6.33 premature deaths per million inhabitants across the region, in 1990, to 7.33 in 2019 (reference).

Cost estimates represent only the cost of premature mortalities. They are calculated using estimates of the “Value of a Statistical Life” (VSL) and the number of premature deaths attributable. They exclude any morbidity impacts (labour productivity losses, treatment costs and willingness to pay to avoid pain and suffering from illness) and impacts other than those on human health (e.g. on built structures, agricultural productivity, ecosystem health). The social cost of the exposure to these environment-related risks is thus greater than the cost of mortalities presented.
Source: OECD (2023), "Air quality and health: Mortality and welfare cost from exposure to air pollution", OECD Environment Statistics (database),

International data on particulate emissions are available for many but not all LAC countries. For example, data on mortality attributed to air pollution exposure, and the associated welfare cost is not available for 25 LAC territories, mostly including Caribbean islands, as well as Uruguay, Venezuela, Suriname and Guatemala. What is more, the estimation methods for emissions, the scope of sources and particles included in estimations, differ from one country to another.

Exposure indicators provide only a partial view of air pollution severity and consequences aggregated across the entire population. Importantly, there is generally no “safe level” of exposure for many pollutants. Even where guideline or target exposures are met, substantial public health and economic benefits can be realised through further improvements in air quality. Better estimates are needed for exposure to both outdoor and indoor air pollution. Particular attention should be paid to exposure of sensitive groups and quantitative impact on human health (and associated distributional and equity issues). Although many important gaps remain, available data are improving.

Welfare costs only account for mortality, while impacts stemming from air pollution and their associated costs are more widely spread, including morbidity, and costs associated to non-human health impacts.
